bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to an Unidentified Recipient, August 20, 1706

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to an Unidentified Recipient, probably a British merchant, August 20, 1706, informing the merchant that since he has declined to take on any business of Ralph Wormeley's estate, it has been sent to others. Carter adds that he and Gawin Corbin drew a bill of exchange on the merchant for some of the estate's quit rents, and that he will write later with instructions about the balance of the estate's funds in the merchant's hands.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to an Unidentified Recipient, August 20, 1706
div1.p:
Yor declining all manner of business tht Small part of Esquire
Wormely designed you is with others varyed into other hands
This only intended to give you advice tht Collo Corbin & my
Self Sometime Since drew on you for £23:15:2 payl to
the proprietors of the Northern Neck being for Quitt rents
due from Land belonging to the Orphans wch must desire
you to pay & Debit tht Estate wth it Iv'e not time to say
more at present hereafter I purpose to be particular
relating to the Balla. of tht Estate in yor hands I remain at present Sr
yor humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, Processioners' Returns, 1711-1783, and Wormeley Estate Papers, 1701-1710, 1716, Acc. 30126, Archives Research Services, Library of Virginia, Richmond, 170.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address,county, and state have been added for clarity to this unheaded, undated letter.
